sentences.sentence: On the fifth day—again, as always, it was thanks to the sheep—the secret of the little prince’s life was revealed( 被揭露 ) to me.
Abruptly( 突然地 ), without anything to lead up to it, and as if the question had been born of long and silent meditation( 沉思 ) on his problem, he demanded:
“A sheep—if it eats little bushes, does it eat flowers, too?”
“A sheep,” I answered, “eats anything it finds in its reach.”
“Even flowers that have thorns( 刺 )?”
“Yes, even flowers that have thorns( 刺 ).”
“Then the thorns( 刺 )—what use are they?”
I did not know.
At that moment I was very busy trying to unscrew( 拧开 ) a bolt( 螺栓 ) that had got stuck in my engine.
I was very much worried, for it was becoming clear to me that the breakdown of my plane was extremely serious.
And I had so little drinking-water left that I had to fear for the worst.
“The thorns( 刺 )—what use are they?”
The little prince never let go of( 放弃 ) a question, once he had asked it. As for me, I was upset over that bolt( 螺栓 ).
And I answered with the first thing that came into my head:
“The thorns( 刺 ) are of no use at all.
Flowers have thorns( 刺 ) just for spite( 恶意 )!”
“Oh!”
There was a moment of complete silence.
Then the little prince flashed back( 愤怒回答 ) at me, with a kind of resentfulness( 愤恨 ):
“I don’t believe you! Flowers are weak creatures. They are naive( 天真的 ). They reassure( 使安心 ) themselves as best they can. They believe that their thorns( 刺 ) are terrible weapons( 武器 ) . . .”
I did not answer.
At that instant I was saying to myself: “If this bolt( 螺栓 ) still won’t turn, I am going to knock it out with the hammer.”
Again the little prince disturbed( 扰乱 ) my thoughts.
“And you actually believe that the flowers—”
“Oh, no!” I cried.
“No, no no! I don’t believe anything. I answered you with the first thing that came into my head. Don’t you see—I am very busy with matters of consequence!”
He stared at me, thunderstruck( 大吃一惊的 ).
“Matters of consequence!”
He looked at me there, with my hammer in my hand, my fingers black with engine-grease( 润滑油 ), bending down over an object which seemed to him extremely ugly . . .
“You talk just like the grown-ups( 成年人 )!”
That made me a little ashamed.
But he went on, relentlessly( 不停地 ):
“You mix everything up together . . . You confuse( 弄混 ) everything . . .”
He was really very angry.
He tossed( 向后甩 ) his golden curls( 鬈发 ) in the breeze( 微风 ).
“I know a planet where there is a certain red-faced gentleman.
He has never smelled a flower. He has never looked at a star. He has never loved any one. He has never done anything in his life but add up figures.
And all day he says over and over, just like you:
‘I am busy with matters of consequence!’ And that makes him swell up with pride( 洋洋自得 ). But he is not a man—he is a mushroom( 蘑菇 )!”
“A what?”
“A mushroom( 蘑菇 )!”
The little prince was now white with rage( 怒气 ).
“The flowers have been growing thorns( 刺 ) for millions of years. For millions of years the sheep have been eating them just the same.
And is it not a matter of consequence to try to understand why the flowers go to so much trouble to grow thorns( 刺 ) which are never of any use to them?
Is the warfare( 战争 ) between the sheep and the flowers not important? Is this not of more consequence than a fat red-faced gentleman’s sums( 算数 )?
And if I know—I, myself—one flower which is unique( 独一无二的 ) in the world, which grows nowhere but on my planet,
but which one little sheep can destroy in a single bite some morning, without even noticing what he is doing—Oh! You think that is not important!”
His face turned from white to red as he continued:
“If someone loves a flower, of which just one single blossom( 花朵 ) grows in all the millions and millions of stars, it is enough to make him happy just to look at the stars.
He can say to himself, ‘Somewhere, my flower is there . . .’
But if the sheep eats the flower, in one moment all his stars will be darkened . . . And you think that is not important!”
He could not say anything more.
His words were choked( 哽咽 ) by sobbing( 啜泣 ).
The night had fallen.
I had let my tools drop from my hands.
Of what moment now was my hammer, my bolt( 螺栓 ), or thirst, or death?
On one star, one planet, my planet, the Earth, there was a little prince to be comforted.
I took him in my arms, and rocked him. I said to him:
“The flower that you love is not in danger. I will draw you a muzzle( 口套 ) for your sheep. I will draw you a railing( 围栏 ) to put around your flower. I will—”
I did not know what to say to him.
I felt awkward( 尴尬的 ) and blundering( 愚蠢的 ).
I did not know how I could reach him, where I could overtake( 赶上 ) him and go on hand in hand with him once more.
It is such a secret place, the land of tears.
I soon learned to know this flower better.
On the little prince’s planet the flowers had always been very simple.
They had only one ring of( 一圈 ) petals( 花瓣 ); they took up no room at all; they were a trouble to nobody.
One morning they would appear in the grass, and by night they would have faded( 枯萎 ) peacefully away.
But one day, from a seed blown from no one knew where, a new flower had come up;
and the little prince had watched very closely over this small sprout( 嫩芽 ) which was not like any other small sprouts( 嫩芽 ) on his planet.
It might, you see, have been a new kind of baobab( 猴面包树 ).
The shrub( 灌木 ) soon stopped growing, and began to get ready to produce a flower.
The little prince, who was present at the first appearance of a huge bud( 花蕾 ), felt at once that some sort of miraculous( 不可思议的 ) apparition( 奇景 ) must emerge( 出现 ) from it.
But the flower was not satisfied to complete the preparations for her beauty in the shelter( 庇护所 ) of her green chamber( 室 ).
She chose her colors with the greatest care.
She adjusted( 整理 ) her petals( 花瓣 ) one by one.
She did not wish to go out into the world all rumpled( 褶皱的 ), like the field poppies( 田野罂粟 ).
It was only in the full radiance( 光彩 ) of her beauty that she wished to appear.
Oh, yes!
She was a coquettish( 卖弄风情的 ) creature!
And her mysterious adornment( 装扮 ) lasted for days and days.

article_info.previous: “我”从和小王子的交谈中得知猴面包树的肆意生长会破坏整个星球。为了让朋友们了解猴面包树的危险，“我”努力的画下猴面包树。而在这期间，“我”发现小王子在他的行星上的唯一乐趣是观看日落。
article_info.share_words: “If someone loves a flower, of which just one single blossom grows in all the millions and millions of stars, it is enough to make him happy just to look at the stars. ”

question.cn: 为什么小王子问“我”问题的时候“我”那么担忧？
question.en: Why was "I" very much worried when the little prince asked "me" questions?

options.en: Because the questions were too difficult.

options.cn: 因为“我”的发动机损坏的很严重。
options.en: Because "my" engine was broken down seriously.
Because the little prince was angry at "me".

analysis: 原文提到：I was very much worried, for it was becoming clear to me that the breakdown of my plane was extremely serious.答案为B。

question.cn: 为什么小王子会生“我”的气？
question.en: Why was the little prince angry at "me"?

options.cn: 因为我一直忙于维修发动机。
options.en: Because "I" was busy with repairing the engine.

analysis: 原文提到：“No, no no! I don’t believe anything. I answered you with the first thing that came into my head. Don’t you see—I am very busy with matters of consequence!”小王子听了这番话后，认为“我”忙于所谓重要的事情而忽略他的问题感到很生气，答案选A。

question.cn: 为什么这朵花儿这么久才绽放?
question.en: Why did it take so long for the flower to blossom?

options.cn: 因为这朵花之前被吃过。
options.en: Because the flower was eaten before.

options.cn: 因为这朵花想以最光彩的一面出现。
options.en: Because the flower wanted to appear in the full radiance of her beauty.

analysis: 原文提到：It was only in the full radiance of her beauty that she wished to appear. 这朵花儿想等自己完全准备好，再完美地绽放，答案为C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第4天
